panel.html:
LinkedIn contains a wealth of information about your organization. Attackers use it to perform reconnaissance, but WE can use it as a source of intelligence as well.
Getting started. Itâ€™s simply useful to know who has associated themselves with your org on LinkedIn. Why? Among other things it makes it very easy to convince legit employees to accept invitations, and then they can see a LOT more detail.
Take for example this brand new user who only connected with Ryan and me. Immediately this user has visibility into hundreds of Splunk users.

panel.title: recon-ng module
panel.html:
The code used in this example is able to pull LinkedIn contact data for an organization without access to the API. This module was created by Richard Warren and submitted to the recon-ng project as a pull request. The code can be viewed here: https://bitbucket.org/LaNMaSteR53/recon-ng/pull-requests/227
Here is a screenshot of the module in use:

table.title: Thanks to the fine folks at PhishMe, we have the results of a recent phishing test performed against the employees of a fictitious organization.

search.query: |inputlookup phishme.csv | table Email "Clicked Link?" "Entered Password?" "Submitted Form" "Reported Phish?"

table.title: sourcetype="xmlwineventlog:microsoft-windows-sysmon/operational" (WINWORD OR EXCEL) EventDescription="Process Create" cmd.exe | lookup phishme Email as user | rename "Submitted Form" as "Known Phish Bait" | table user "Known Phish Bait" ParentCommandLine CommandLine

search.query: sourcetype="xmlwineventlog:microsoft-windows-sysmon/operational" (WINWORD OR EXCEL) EventDescription="Process Create" cmd.exe | lookup phishme Email as user | rename "Submitted Form" as "Known Phish Bait" | table user "Known Phish Bait" ParentCommandLine CommandLine
